Title:
Circumscription and phylogeny of the Lepidostromatales
following discovery of new species from China and Africa
Abstract:
The circumscription of and generic concepts in the
Lepidostromales, a lineage of clavarioid lichen-forming basidiomycetes,
have significantly evolved following phylogenetic inferences.
Multiclavula was revealed as phylogenetically heterogeneous, comprising
species of Multiclavula s.str. (Cantherellales) and Lepidostroma
(Lepidostromatales). Clavarioid lichen-forming basidiomycetes of China
are currently accommodated in six species and treated as members of
Multiclavula. Based on an exhaustive sampling of all known
Lepidostromatales we assess 1) the phylogenetic affinities of the
Chinese species based on inferences from the small and large subunits of
the nuclear ribosomal DNA repeat and 2) the phylogenetic structure among
Chinese populations of Lepidostroma, based on the ITS regions.
Multiclavula fossicola and M. sinensis are shown to belong to the
Lepidostromatales, and are transferred to Sulzbacheromyces. Chinese
reports of M. clara and M. vernalis belong to species of
Lepidostromatales and specimens of M. mucida belong to the
non-lichenized Clavaria, and hence evidence of Multiclavula in China is
lacking. Similarly, L. calocerum is excluded from the Chinese flora. The
recently described L. asianum should be treated as conspecific with S.
sinensis. Three new species of Sulzbacheromyces are described: S.
bicolor and S. yunnanensis from China, and S. miomboensis from the
Democratic Republic of Congo. Consequently, Sulzbacheromyces is new to
Asia and Africa. A world-wide key to the species of Lepidostromatales is
provided. Finally the meloid beetle Mylabris cichorii, is reported to
eat the basidiomata of S. yunnanensis, which may suggest that this
insect plays an active role in the dispersal of the lichenized
basidiolichen.
